@pbxpb, this is a full widescreen aspect ratio, so because cinema screens are wider than our monitors, the only way to present the movie it its original screen ratio, is to present it with the black bars.  When you watch a movie without the black bars, you're actually watching a chopped version (properly called pan & scan), so you actually had that the wrong way around.  Widescreen = original, fullscreen = chopped.

Two Towers goes out of sync 1:51:10 (line 3)
Return of the King goes out of sync 2:12:51 (line 5)

I play most of my films through my PS3. I run them through MKV2VOB, maintaining the DTS audio track. However, my receiver and 5.1 setup do not support DTS-HD MA, and I have an older 60gb (fat) PS3 so it does not support DTS-HD MA either. The specifications for these files note that the audio track is 6.1 DTS-HD MA. 
   So, my question is...will the PS3 or receiver automatically scale down the signal to make it compatible, similar to how 5.1 AC3 can be automatically scaled down to 2 channel? If not, will the muxing program solve the issue whilst maintaining the DTS format and bitrate (rather than scaling the entire audio track down to 640kbs AC3)? If anyone could please provide me with some answers or point me in the right direction, it would be greatly appreciated. I don't want to download an 80gb film because of visual improvments (I have the previous 1080p extended edition release already) only to sacrifice audio quality. Thanks!
   And above all else, thanks to the rippers, encoders, uploaders, seeders, and EVERYONE who contributed to the films!
